newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SAfrica's Mandela to meet Zaire's Kabila Wednesday.
newsitem.headline: SAfrica's Mandela to meet Zaire's Kabila Wednesday.

text.p: South African President Nelson Mandela, driving an African initiative for peace in eastern Zaire, will meet Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila in Johannesburg on Wednesday, a spokesman said.
"The President will meet Kabila at his house in Johannesburg just to shake hands -- for a very, very general discussion," presidential spokesman Parks Mankahlana told Reuters by telephone.

Mandela, just back from Botswana where he attended a Commonwealth policy meeting on governance in Africa, was expected to travel to his Johannesburg home to meet Kabila later on Wednesday, Mankahlana said.
He said Mandela remained committed to an early meeting with Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko, but probably would travel to Zaire with other African leaders for the talks.
"His idea is that a delegation of heads of state should go to Zaire to meet President Mobutu there," Mankahlana said.
Mandela told reporters earlier this week he hoped to meet Mobutu in Kenya or Zaire on March 19. Officials said this date had however not been confirmed.
Mankahlana said Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad, who on Wednesday anchored proximity talks involving Kabila, briefed Mandela at the Waterkloof military airbase near Pretoria.
Diplomats said U.S. Assistant Secretary of State George Moose, who is visiting South Africa, also met Kabila on Wednesday.

Officials declined to say whether Pahad was able to report progress to Mandela, who last week announced a new South African-led initiative for peace in Zaire, where the government is fighting ethnic Tutsi rebels.

Mankahlana said Mandela, who leaves for Southeast Asia on Friday, wanted to give his personal encouragement to the peace process, about which officials and diplomats have so far remained tight-lipped.
"The President expressed the wish to meet Kabila and shake his hand. The President is not going to go into any hard discussion.
"The intention is to encourage Kabila to play the role that President Mandela believes he is capable of playing in Zaire. Kabila is obviously a very important player," he said.
Kabila's rebels, many of them Zairean Tutsis whose ethnic kin control neighbouring Rwanda and Burundi, took up arms last October and have overrun a swath of east Zaire's borderlands.

The conflict, which escalated this month with the aerial bombing of rebel-held towns, has sent tens of thousands of refugees fleeing and threatens to destabilise Zaire and its Central African neighbours.
